summary: Despite the strong performance achieved by reinforcement learning-trained information-seeking agents, learning in open-ended web environments remains severely constrained by low signal-to-noise feedback. Text-based parsers often discard layout semantics and introduce unstructured noise, while long-horizon training typically relies on sparse outcome rewards that obscure which retrieval actions actually matter. We propose a visual-native search framework that represents webpages as visual snapshots, allowing agents to leverage layout cues to quickly localize salient evidence and suppress distractors. To learn effectively from these high-dimensional observations, we introduce Information-Aware Credit Assignment (ICA), a post-hoc method that estimates each retrieved snapshot's contribution to the final outcome via posterior analysis and propagates dense learning signals back to key search turns. Integrated with a GRPO-based training pipeline, our approach consistently outperforms text-based baselines on diverse information-seeking benchmarks, providing evidence that visual snapshot grounding with information-level credit assignment alleviates the credit-assignment bottleneck in open-ended web environments. The code and datasets will be released in https://github.com/pc-inno/ICA_MM_deepsearch.git.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a visual-native search framework paired with Information-Aware Credit Assignment (ICA) to improve reinforcement learning in open-ended web environments, addressing noise and sparse feedback challenges.
AI.motivation: Learning in open-ended web environments faces challenges from sparse outcome rewards and unstructured noise due to text-based parsers. The need is to effectively localize important information amidst noise and provide dense learning signals to train agents.
AI.method: The paper introduces a visual-native search framework that uses webpage snapshots to retain layout semantics and suppress distractors. It employs Information-Aware Credit Assignment (ICA) to estimate key contributions of retrieved snapshots through dense signals via a GRPO-based training process.
AI.result: The approach outperforms text-based baselines across diverse information-seeking benchmarks, demonstrating stronger performance in suppressing distractors and enhancing learning.
AI.conclusion: The method effectively alleviates the credit-assignment bottleneck in open-ended web environments and enables better information retrieval. Resources including code and datasets are made available to aid further research.

title: The Sample Complexity of Uniform Approximation for Multi-Dimensional CDFs and Fixed-Price Mechanisms
summary: We study the sample complexity of learning a uniform approximation of an $n$-dimensional cumulative distribution function (CDF) within an error $ε> 0$, when observations are restricted to a minimal one-bit feedback. This serves as a counterpart to the multivariate DKW inequality under ''full feedback'', extending it to the setting of ''bandit feedback''. Our main result shows a near-dimensional-invariance in the sample complexity: we get a uniform $ε$-approximation with a sample complexity $\frac{1}{ε^3}{\log\left(\frac 1 ε\right)^{\mathcal{O}(n)}}$ over a arbitrary fine grid, where the dimensionality $n$ only affects logarithmic terms. As direct corollaries, we provide tight sample complexity bounds and novel regret guarantees for learning fixed-price mechanisms in small markets, such as bilateral trade settings.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the sample complexity of learning uniform approximations of multivariate CDFs using minimal one-bit feedback and provides a near-dimensional-invariant result.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to extend the multivariate DKW inequality from full feedback to a more restricted bandit feedback setting.
AI.method: The authors analyze the sample complexity required for uniform approximation of a CDF over fine grids, deriving bounds with a dependence of $\mathcal{O}(n)$ only in logarithmic terms.
AI.result: The study demonstrates that uniform $\epsilon$-approximations can be achieved with sample complexity of $\frac{1}{\epsilon^3} \log(1/\epsilon)^{\mathcal{O}(n)}$, indicating minimal impact of dimensionality on sample size requirements.
AI.conclusion: The findings provide insights into low-complexity learning in limited feedback settings and enable tight sample complexity bounds and regret guarantees for applications such as fixed-price mechanisms in small markets.

title: FedPS: Federated data Preprocessing via aggregated Statistics
summary: Federated Learning (FL) enables multiple parties to collaboratively train machine learning models without sharing raw data. However, before training, data must be preprocessed to address missing values, inconsistent formats, and heterogeneous feature scales. This preprocessing stage is critical for model performance but is largely overlooked in FL research. In practical FL systems, privacy constraints prohibit centralizing raw data, while communication efficiency introduces further challenges for distributed preprocessing. We introduce FedPS, a unified framework for federated data preprocessing based on aggregated statistics. FedPS leverages data-sketching techniques to efficiently summarize local datasets while preserving essential statistical information. Building on these summaries, we design federated algorithms for feature scaling, encoding, discretization, and missing-value imputation, and extend preprocessing-related models such as k-Means, k-Nearest Neighbors, and Bayesian Linear Regression to both horizontal and vertical FL settings. FedPS provides flexible, communication-efficient, and consistent preprocessing pipelines for practical FL deployments.

AI.tldr: FedPS introduces federated preprocessing using aggregated statistics to improve FL systems' data preparation without requiring raw data sharing.
AI.motivation: To address the lack of attention on preprocessing in Federated Learning, which is critical for model performance but restricted by privacy and communication constraints.
AI.method: By leveraging data-sketching techniques, FedPS efficiently summarizes local datasets into aggregated statistics for distributed preprocessing tasks such as feature scaling, encoding, and missing-value handling.
AI.result: FedPS extends preprocessing models like k-Means and Bayesian Linear Regression, offering flexible and efficient preprocessing pipelines compatible with FL systems.
AI.conclusion: FedPS enhances Federated Learning by tackling distributed preprocessing challenges, ensuring scalable data preparation while adhering to privacy and communication constraints.

title: Resource-Efficient Model-Free Reinforcement Learning for Board Games
summary: Board games have long served as complex decision-making benchmarks in artificial intelligence. In this field, search-based reinforcement learning methods such as AlphaZero have achieved remarkable success. However, their significant computational demands have been pointed out as barriers to their reproducibility. In this study, we propose a model-free reinforcement learning algorithm designed for board games to achieve more efficient learning. To validate the efficiency of the proposed method, we conducted comprehensive experiments on five board games: Animal Shogi, Gardner Chess, Go, Hex, and Othello. The results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves more efficient learning than existing methods across these environments. In addition, our extensive ablation study shows the importance of core techniques used in the proposed method. We believe that our efficient algorithm shows the potential of model-free reinforcement learning in domains traditionally dominated by search-based methods.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a model-free reinforcement learning algorithm for board games, which outperforms existing methods in efficiency across various games.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the computational demands of traditional search-based reinforcement learning methods, such as AlphaZero, and make these approaches more reproducible and efficient.
AI.method: The authors propose a model-free reinforcement learning algorithm specifically tailored for board games and validate its performance through comprehensive experiments and ablation studies.
AI.result: The proposed method demonstrates more efficient learning compared to existing methods across five board games: Animal Shogi, Gardner Chess, Go, Hex, and Othello.
AI.conclusion: The findings highlight the potential of model-free reinforcement learning as a viable alternative to search-based methods in board game AI, showcasing its efficiency and importance of specific core techniques.

title: The Neurosymbolic Frontier of Nonuniform Ellipticity: Formalizing Sharp Schauder Theory via Topos-Theoretic Reasoning Models
summary: This white paper presents a critical synthesis of the recent breakthrough in nonuniformly elliptic regularity theory and the burgeoning field of neurosymbolic large reasoning models (LRMs). We explore the resolution of the long-standing sharp growth rate conjecture in Schauder theory, achieved by Cristiana De Filippis and Giuseppe Mingione, which identifies the exact threshold $q/p < 1 + α/n$ for gradient Hölder continuity. Central to this mathematical achievement is the ``ghost equation'' methodology, a sophisticated auxiliary derivation that bypasses the non-differentiability of classical Euler-Lagrange systems. We propose that the next era of mathematical discovery lies in the integration of these pure analytical constructs with LRMs grounded in topos theory and formal verification frameworks such as Safe and Typed Chain-of-Thought (PC-CoT). By modeling the reasoning process as a categorical colimit in a slice topos, we demonstrate how LRMs can autonomously navigate the ``Dark Side'' of the calculus of variations, providing machine-checkable proofs for regularity bounds in complex, multi-phase physical systems.

AI.tldr: The paper integrates recent advancements in elliptic regularity theory with neurosymbolic reasoning models to push mathematical understanding and automated proof capabilities.
AI.motivation: To combine mathematical breakthroughs in elliptic regularity and cutting-edge neurosymbolic models to explore new avenues in automated reasoning and regularity theory.
AI.method: Utilizes the ‘ghost equation’ in mathematical analyses and integrates reasoning frameworks such as Safe and Typed Chain-of-Thought within the categorical framework of topos theory for modeling and proving.
AI.result: Defines a way for neurosymbolic models to autonomously address complex problems in calculus of variations and provide machine-verified proofs.
AI.conclusion: The synthesis presents a pathway for expanding automated mathematical reasoning, utilizing both mathematical innovations and neurosymbolic reasoning frameworks.

title: Tuning the burn-in phase in training recurrent neural networks improves their performance
comment: Published as a conference paper at ICLR 2026, https://openreview.net/forum?id=jwkdKpioHJ
summary: Training recurrent neural networks (RNNs) with standard backpropagation through time (BPTT) can be challenging, especially in the presence of long input sequences. A practical alternative to reduce computational and memory overhead is to perform BPTT repeatedly over shorter segments of the training data set, corresponding to truncated BPTT. In this paper, we examine the training of RNNs when using such a truncated learning approach for time series tasks. Specifically, we establish theoretical bounds on the accuracy and performance loss when optimizing over subsequences instead of the full data sequence. This reveals that the burn-in phase of the RNN is an important tuning knob in its training, with significant impact on the performance guarantees. We validate our theoretical results through experiments on standard benchmarks from the fields of system identification and time series forecasting. In all experiments, we observe a strong influence of the burn-in phase on the training process, and proper tuning can lead to a reduction of the prediction error on the training and test data of more than 60% in some cases.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates the training of recurrent neural networks (RNNs) using truncated backpropagation through time (BPTT) for time series tasks, showing the key role of the burn-in phase in improving accuracy and performance.
AI.motivation: To address the difficulties and inefficiencies in training RNNs over long sequences via standard BPTT, making truncated BPTT more effective for time series tasks.
AI.method: The study theoretically examines and establishes performance bounds of RNN training under truncated BPTT, focusing on the burn-in phase's role and validates findings through experiments on standard time series benchmarks.
AI.result: The experiments confirm that proper tuning of the burn-in phase can significantly improve prediction results, with a reduction of over 60% in prediction error in some cases.
AI.conclusion: Tuning the burn-in phase during truncated BPTT training is crucial for enhancing prediction accuracy and lowering errors in RNNs for time series tasks.

title: Near-Constant Strong Violation and Last-Iterate Convergence for Online CMDPs via Decaying Safety Margins
summary: We study safe online reinforcement learning in Constrained Markov Decision Processes (CMDPs) under strong regret and violation metrics, which forbid error cancellation over time. Existing primal-dual methods that achieve sublinear strong reward regret inevitably incur growing strong constraint violation or are restricted to average-iterate convergence due to inherent oscillations. To address these limitations, we propose the Flexible safety Domain Optimization via Margin-regularized Exploration (FlexDOME) algorithm, the first to provably achieve near-constant $\tilde{O}(1)$ strong constraint violation alongside sublinear strong regret and non-asymptotic last-iterate convergence. FlexDOME incorporates time-varying safety margins and regularization terms into the primal-dual framework. Our theoretical analysis relies on a novel term-wise asymptotic dominance strategy, where the safety margin is rigorously scheduled to asymptotically majorize the functional decay rates of the optimization and statistical errors, thereby clamping cumulative violations to a near-constant level. Furthermore, we establish non-asymptotic last-iterate convergence guarantees via a policy-dual Lyapunov argument. Experiments corroborate our theoretical findings.

AI.tldr: FlexDOME offers a novel approach for safe online reinforcement learning in CMDPs by addressing the limitations of existing primal-dual methods, achieving near-constant constraint violation and last-iterate convergence.
AI.motivation: To overcome the challenges in existing primal-dual methods that struggle with oscillations, growing constraint violations, or average convergence.
AI.method: FlexDOME utilizes time-varying safety margins and regularization terms, alongside a novel term-wise asymptotic dominance strategy and policy-dual Lyapunov analysis.
AI.result: FlexDOME achieves near-constant constraint violation, sublinear regret, and non-asymptotic last-iterate convergence.
AI.conclusion: FlexDOME provides significant improvements in safe reinforcement learning under CMDPs, achieving theoretical advances and corroborated experimental results.

title: Spatial-Morphological Modeling for Multi-Attribute Imputation of Urban Blocks
summary: Accurate reconstruction of missing morphological indicators of a city is crucial for urban planning and data-driven analysis. This study presents the spatial-morphological (SM) imputer tool, which combines data-driven morphological clustering with neighborhood-based methods to reconstruct missing values of the floor space index (FSI) and ground space index (GSI) at the city block level, inspired by the SpaceMatrix framework. This approach combines city-scale morphological patterns as global priors with local spatial information for context-dependent interpolation. The evaluation shows that while SM alone captures meaningful morphological structure, its combination with inverse distance weighting (IDW) or spatial k-nearest neighbor (sKNN) methods provides superior performance compared to existing SOTA models. Composite methods demonstrate the complementary advantages of combining morphological and spatial approaches.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces the SM imputer tool for reconstructing missing urban morphological indicators combining global morphological patterns and local spatial methods, outperforming state-of-the-art models.
AI.motivation: Accurate reconstruction of morphological indicators like FSI and GSI is vital for urban planning and data analysis.
AI.method: The SM imputer integrates data-driven morphological clustering with neighborhood-based interpolation methods like IDW or spatial k-NN.
AI.result: The combination of SM with spatial methods outperforms state-of-the-art methods by leveraging complementary strengths of both approaches.
AI.conclusion: Blending global morphological patterns and local spatial data produces a more accurate reconstruction of missing urban indicators and enhances current modeling practices.

title: CMAD: Cooperative Multi-Agent Diffusion via Stochastic Optimal Control
summary: Continuous-time generative models have achieved remarkable success in image restoration and synthesis. However, controlling the composition of multiple pre-trained models remains an open challenge. Current approaches largely treat composition as an algebraic composition of probability densities, such as via products or mixtures of experts. This perspective assumes the target distribution is known explicitly, which is almost never the case. In this work, we propose a different paradigm that formulates compositional generation as a cooperative Stochastic Optimal Control problem. Rather than combining probability densities, we treat pre-trained diffusion models as interacting agents whose diffusion trajectories are jointly steered, via optimal control, toward a shared objective defined on their aggregated output. We validate our framework on conditional MNIST generation and compare it against a naive inference-time DPS-style baseline replacing learned cooperative control with per-step gradient guidance.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a novel approach to composing multiple pre-trained continuous-time generative models by formulating it as a cooperative Stochastic Optimal Control problem, treating models as interacting agents instead of manipulating probability densities.
AI.motivation: To address the challenge of controlling the composition of multiple pre-trained continuous-time generative models, which current methods poorly handle by focusing on algebraic transformations of probability densities.
AI.method: The paper proposes treating pre-trained diffusion models as interacting agents, using cooperative Stochastic Optimal Control to guide their trajectories toward a shared objective defined on their aggregated results, instead of explicitly combining probability densities.
AI.result: The proposed framework demonstrates its effectiveness in conditional MNIST generation, outperforming a naive baseline that substitutes cooperative control with per-step gradient guidance.
AI.conclusion: The work establishes a new paradigm for compositional generation, showcasing how diffusion models can cooperate via optimal control to achieve complex objectives collaboratively.

title: Stochastic Parroting in Temporal Attention -- Regulating the Diagonal Sink
summary: Spatio-temporal models analyze spatial structures and temporal dynamics, which makes them prone to information degeneration among space and time. Prior literature has demonstrated that over-squashing in causal attention or temporal convolutions creates a bias on the first tokens. To analyze whether such a bias is present in temporal attention mechanisms, we derive sensitivity bounds on the expected value of the Jacobian of a temporal attention layer. We theoretically show how off-diagonal attention scores depend on the sequence length, and that temporal attention matrices suffer a diagonal attention sink. We suggest regularization methods, and experimentally demonstrate their effectiveness.

AI.tldr: The paper explores information degeneration in spatio-temporal models, identifies biases in temporal attention mechanisms caused by diagonal attention sinks, and proposes regularization methods with experimental validation.
AI.motivation: The study seeks to address over-squashing and biases in causal attention or temporal convolutions that negatively impact spatio-temporal models by focusing on degeneration issues in temporal attention mechanisms.
AI.method: The authors derive sensitivity bounds on the Jacobian of a temporal attention layer, analyze off-diagonal attention scores, identify the diagonal attention sink, and suggest regularization methods.
AI.result: The paper theoretically proves the existence of diagonal attention sink in temporal attention matrices and demonstrates the effectiveness of their proposed regularization methods in experiments.
AI.conclusion: Temporal attention mechanisms are prone to biases due to diagonal sinks, but regularization methods can alleviate these issues and improve information retention in temporal models.

title: Cross-Sectional Asset Retrieval via Future-Aligned Soft Contrastive Learning
summary: Asset retrieval--finding similar assets in a financial universe--is central to quantitative investment decision-making. Existing approaches define similarity through historical price patterns or sector classifications, but such backward-looking criteria provide no guarantee about future behavior. We argue that effective asset retrieval should be future-aligned: the retrieved assets should be those most likely to exhibit correlated future returns. To this end, we propose Future-Aligned Soft Contrastive Learning (FASCL), a representation learning framework whose soft contrastive loss uses pairwise future return correlations as continuous supervision targets. We further introduce an evaluation protocol designed to directly assess whether retrieved assets share similar future trajectories. Experiments on 4,229 US equities demonstrate that FASCL consistently outperforms 13 baselines across all future-behavior metrics. The source code will be available soon.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes Future-Aligned Soft Contrastive Learning (FASCL) for asset retrieval based on future returns instead of backward-looking criteria, achieving better performance.
AI.motivation: To move beyond backward-looking criteria (historical price patterns, sector classifications) for asset retrieval and focus on retrieving assets that share correlated future returns.
AI.method: The paper introduces FASCL, a representation learning framework with a soft contrastive loss supervised by pairwise future return correlations. An evaluation protocol is also developed to measure similarity in future trajectories.
AI.result: FASCL outperforms 13 baseline models across all future-behavior metrics in experiments involving 4,229 US equities.
AI.conclusion: FASCL is an effective approach for future-aligned asset retrieval, showing superior results and demonstrating the importance of considering future behaviors for quantitative investment decision-making.

title: MoEEdit: Efficient and Routing-Stable Knowledge Editing for Mixture-of-Experts LLMs
summary: Knowledge editing (KE) enables precise modifications to factual content in large language models (LLMs). Existing KE methods are largely designed for dense architectures, limiting their applicability to the increasingly prevalent sparse Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models that underpin modern scalable LLMs. Although MoEs offer strong efficiency and capacity scaling, naively adapting dense-model editors is both computationally costly and prone to routing distribution shifts that undermine stability and consistency. To address these challenges, we introduce MoEEdit, the first routing-stable framework for parameter-modifying knowledge editing in MoE LLMs. Our method reparameterizes expert updates via per-expert null-space projections that keep router inputs invariant and thereby suppress routing shifts. The resulting block-structured optimization is solved efficiently with a block coordinate descent (BCD) solver. Experiments show that MoEEdit attains state-of-the-art efficacy and generalization while preserving high specificity and routing stability, with superior compute and memory efficiency. These results establish a robust foundation for scalable, precise knowledge editing in sparse LLMs and underscore the importance of routing-stable interventions.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces MoEEdit, a framework enabling stable and efficient knowledge editing in sparse Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models used in Large Language Models (LLMs).
AI.motivation: Existing methods for knowledge editing focus on dense architectures and are unsuitable for the increasingly popular sparse Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models, which face challenges of efficiency, stability, and routing consistency when naively adapted.
AI.method: The proposed MoEEdit introduces per-expert null-space projections to reparameterize expert updates, ensuring router input invariance and stability. It employs a block coordinate descent solver for efficient optimization.
AI.result: MoEEdit achieves state-of-the-art performance in efficacy, generalization, and routing stability, all while maintaining high specificity and superior compute and memory efficiency.
AI.conclusion: MoEEdit provides a robust method for precise knowledge editing in sparse LLMs, highlighting the importance of routing-stable approaches for such architectures.

title: RiemannGL: Riemannian Geometry Changes Graph Deep Learning
summary: Graphs are ubiquitous, and learning on graphs has become a cornerstone in artificial intelligence and data mining communities. Unlike pixel grids in images or sequential structures in language, graphs exhibit a typical non-Euclidean structure with complex interactions among the objects. This paper argues that Riemannian geometry provides a principled and necessary foundation for graph representation learning, and that Riemannian graph learning should be viewed as a unifying paradigm rather than a collection of isolated techniques. While recent studies have explored the integration of graph learning and Riemannian geometry, most existing approaches are limited to a narrow class of manifolds, particularly hyperbolic spaces, and often adopt extrinsic manifold formulations. We contend that the central mission of Riemannian graph learning is to endow graph neural networks with intrinsic manifold structures, which remains underexplored. To advance this perspective, we identify key conceptual and methodological gaps in existing approaches and outline a structured research agenda along three dimensions: manifold type, neural architecture, and learning paradigm. We further discuss open challenges, theoretical foundations, and promising directions that are critical for unlocking the full potential of Riemannian graph learning. This paper aims to provide a coherent viewpoint and to stimulate broader exploration of Riemannian geometry as a foundational framework for future graph learning research.

AI.tldr: The paper focuses on integrating Riemannian geometry into graph representation learning, proposing it as a unifying framework and addressing conceptual gaps in current methods.
AI.motivation: The current graph learning approaches are restricted by non-Euclidean structures and are narrowly applied to specific manifolds like hyperbolic spaces. There is a lack of a systematic principle using Riemannian geometry for graph learning.
AI.method: The paper identifies shortcomings in current Riemannian graph learning approaches and proposes a structured agenda focusing on manifold types, neural architectures, and learning paradigms.
AI.result: The paper provides a coherent viewpoint on integrating intrinsic manifold structures into graph learning and outlines open challenges and future research directions.
AI.conclusion: Riemannian geometry appears to be crucial for advancing the foundation of graph representation learning, encouraging broader investigations and exploration.

title: Sample Efficient Generative Molecular Optimization with Joint Self-Improvement
summary: Generative molecular optimization aims to design molecules with properties surpassing those of existing compounds. However, such candidates are rare and expensive to evaluate, yielding sample efficiency essential. Additionally, surrogate models introduced to predict molecule evaluations, suffer from distribution shift as optimization drives candidates increasingly out-of-distribution. To address these challenges, we introduce Joint Self-Improvement, which benefits from (i) a joint generative-predictive model and (ii) a self-improving sampling scheme. The former aligns the generator with the surrogate, alleviating distribution shift, while the latter biases the generative part of the joint model using the predictive one to efficiently generate optimized molecules at inference-time. Experiments across offline and online molecular optimization benchmarks demonstrate that Joint Self-Improvement outperforms state-of-the-art methods under limited evaluation budgets.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Joint Self-Improvement, combining a generative-predictive model and a self-improving sampling scheme to address sample efficiency and distribution shift challenges in generative molecular optimization.
AI.motivation: Design molecules that surpass existing compounds while addressing the issues of sample efficiency and distribution shift during surrogate-driven optimization.
AI.method: Joint Self-Improvement combines (i) a joint generative-predictive model to align the generator and surrogate models and (ii) a self-improving sampling scheme for efficient molecule generation during inference.
AI.result: Demonstrated superior performance of Joint Self-Improvement compared to state-of-the-art methods under constrained evaluation budgets across various molecular optimization benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Joint Self-Improvement effectively generates optimized molecules by addressing key challenges, offering a promising framework for molecular design.

title: TVCACHE: A Stateful Tool-Value Cache for Post-Training LLM Agents
comment: Abhishek Vijaya Kumar and Bhaskar Kataria have equal contribution
summary: In RL post-training of LLM agents, calls to external tools take several seconds or even minutes, leaving allocated GPUs idle and inflating post-training time and cost. While many tool invocations repeat across parallel rollouts and could in principle be cached, naively caching their outputs for reuse is incorrect since tool outputs depend on the environment state induced by prior agent interactions. We present TVCACHE, a stateful tool-value cache for LLM agent post-training. TVCACHE maintains a tree of observed tool-call sequences and performs longest-prefix matching for cache lookups: a hit occurs only when the agent's full tool history matches a previously executed sequence, guaranteeing identical environment state. On three diverse workloads-terminal-based tasks, SQL generation, and video understanding. TVCACHE achieves cache hit rates of up to 70% and reduces median tool call execution time by up to 6.9X, with no degradation in post-training reward accumulation.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces TVCACHE, a stateful caching mechanism for LLM post-training that significantly reduces tool invocation time while ensuring correct state-dependent responses.
AI.motivation: To address the inefficiencies and costs associated with delayed external tool calls during reinforcement learning (RL) post-training of large language model (LLM) agents and ensure correctness in state-dependent results when caching.
AI.method: The authors develop TVCACHE, using a tree-based tool-call sequence tracking and longest-prefix matching to ensure accurate cache hits based on the agent's interaction history and induced environment states.
AI.result: Experiments across tasks like terminal operations, SQL generation, and video understanding exhibit up to 70% cache hit rates and a median reduction in tool execution time by up to 6.9X, without compromising post-training performance rewards.
AI.conclusion: TVCACHE offers an effective solution to accelerate RL post-training in LLM agents by leveraging stateful caching, resulting in substantial time and cost savings without compromising performance.

title: When Fusion Helps and When It Breaks: View-Aligned Robustness in Same-Source Financial Imaging
summary: We study same-source multi-view learning and adversarial robustness for next-day direction prediction with financial image representations. On Shanghai Gold Exchange (SGE) spot gold data (2005-2025), we construct two window-aligned views from each rolling window: an OHLCV-rendered price/volume chart and a technical-indicator matrix. To ensure reliable evaluation, we adopt leakage-resistant time-block splits with embargo and use Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC). We find that results depend strongly on the label-noise regime: we apply an ex-post minimum-movement filter that discards samples with realized next-day absolute return below tau to define evaluation subsets with reduced near-zero label ambiguity. This induces a non-monotonic data-noise trade-off that can reveal predictive signal but eventually increases variance as sample size shrinks; the filter is used for offline benchmark construction rather than an inference-time decision rule. In the stabilized subsets, fusion is regime dependent: early fusion by channel stacking can exhibit negative transfer, whereas late fusion with dual encoders and a fusion head provides the dominant clean-performance gains; cross-view consistency regularization has secondary, backbone-dependent effects. We further evaluate test-time L-infinity perturbations using FGSM and PGD under two threat scenarios: view-constrained attacks that perturb one view and joint attacks that perturb both. We observe severe vulnerability at tiny budgets with strong view asymmetry. Late fusion consistently improves robustness under view-constrained attacks, but joint attacks remain challenging and can still cause substantial worst-case degradation.

AI.tldr: This paper examines multi-view learning and adversarial robustness for predicting financial market direction using price/volume charts and technical-indicator matrices. It emphasizes robust evaluation and analyzes trade-offs between data noise and predictive performance.
AI.motivation: To improve financial market prediction by leveraging multi-view learning with financial image representations and addressing challenges related to evaluation reliability, label noise, and adversarial robustness.
AI.method: The authors constructed two views from gold market data, applied a minimum-movement filter to reduce label noise, and tested early vs. late fusion techniques. They evaluated adversarial robustness under view-constrained and joint attack scenarios using FGSM and PGD methods.
AI.result: Late fusion with dual encoders showed superior predictive performance and robustness against view-constrained attacks. However, joint adversarial attacks posed a significant challenge, leading to performance degradation.
AI.conclusion: Late fusion strategies enhance prediction performance and robustness in financial multi-view learning, though combating joint adversarial attacks remains a critical challenge.

title: Divide, Harmonize, Then Conquer It: Shooting Multi-Commodity Flow Problems with Multimodal Language Models
comment: Published as a conference paper at ICLR 2026
summary: The multi-commodity flow (MCF) problem is a fundamental topic in network flow and combinatorial optimization, with broad applications in transportation, communication, and logistics, etc. Nowadays, the rapid expansion of allocation systems has posed challenges for existing optimization engines in balancing optimality and tractability. In this paper, we present Pram, the first ML-based method that leverages the reasoning power of multimodal language models (MLMs) for addressing the trade-off dilemma -- a great need of service providers. As part of our proposal, Pram (i) quickly computes high-quality allocations by dividing the original problem into local subproblems, which are then resolved by an MLM-powered "agent", and (ii) ensures global consistency by harmonizing these subproblems via a multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm. Theoretically, we show that Pram, which learns to perform gradient descent in context, provably converges to the optimum within the family of MCF problems. Empirically, on real-world datasets and public topologies, Pram achieves performance comparable to, and in some cases even surpassing, linear programming solvers (very close to the optimal solution), and substantially lower runtimes (1 to 2 orders of magnitude faster). Moreover, Pram exhibits strong robustness (<10\% performance degradation under link failures or flow bursts), demonstrating MLM's generalization ability to unforeseen events. Pram is objective-agnostic and seamlessly integrates with mainstream allocation systems, providing a practical and scalable solution for future networks.

AI.tldr: Pram, an ML-based method, addresses the multi-commodity flow (MCF) problem using multimodal language models (MLMs), achieving faster runtime and high-quality allocations while maintaining robustness.
AI.motivation: To tackle challenges in optimization engines balancing optimality and tractability in the rapidly expanding allocation systems.
AI.method: Pram divides the MCF problem into local subproblems resolved by MLM-powered agents, ensuring global consistency via multi-agent reinforcement learning, and theoretically learns gradient descent for convergence.
AI.result: Pram exhibits performance comparable to or surpassing linear programming solvers, is faster (1-2 magnitudes), and shows strong robustness under unforeseen events.
AI.conclusion: Pram integrates seamlessly with allocation systems, providing scalable and practical solutions for future networks.

title: MoToRec: Sparse-Regularized Multimodal Tokenization for Cold-Start Recommendation
summary: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have revolutionized recommender systems by effectively modeling complex user-item interactions, yet data sparsity and the item cold-start problem significantly impair performance, particularly for new items with limited or no interaction history. While multimodal content offers a promising solution, existing methods result in suboptimal representations for new items due to noise and entanglement in sparse data. To address this, we transform multimodal recommendation into discrete semantic tokenization. We present Sparse-Regularized Multimodal Tokenization for Cold-Start Recommendation (MoToRec), a framework centered on a sparsely-regularized Residual Quantized Variational Autoencoder (RQ-VAE) that generates a compositional semantic code of discrete, interpretable tokens, promoting disentangled representations. MoToRec's architecture is enhanced by three synergistic components: (1) a sparsely-regularized RQ-VAE that promotes disentangled representations, (2) a novel adaptive rarity amplification that promotes prioritized learning for cold-start items, and (3) a hierarchical multi-source graph encoder for robust signal fusion with collaborative signals. Extensive experiments on three large-scale datasets demonstrate MoToRec's superiority over state-of-the-art methods in both overall and cold-start scenarios. Our work validates that discrete tokenization provides an effective and scalable alternative for mitigating the long-standing cold-start challenge.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces MoToRec, a framework using discrete semantic tokenization to address cold-start recommendation issues in GNNs, significantly improving performance on sparse and new data.
AI.motivation: Graph neural networks excel in recommender systems but face challenges with data sparsity and the item cold-start problem, particularly for new items without interaction history. Multimodal content methods struggle with noise and representation quality, necessitating improved solutions.
AI.method: The authors propose MoToRec, a framework based on sparse-regularized Residual Quantized Variational Autoencoder (RQ-VAE). It generates disentangled and interpretable semantic tokens for recommendations. The framework incorporates three key innovations: sparsely-regularized RQ-VAE for representation disentanglement, adaptive rarity amplification for better cold-start performance, and a hierarchical multi-source graph encoder for collaborative signal fusion.
AI.result: MoToRec outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both overall and cold-start scenarios, as demonstrated through experiments on three large-scale datasets.
AI.conclusion: Discrete tokenization, as implemented in MoToRec, is shown to be an effective, scalable method for addressing cold-start challenges in recommender systems, outperforming existing approaches.

title: Motion Capture is Not the Target Domain: Scaling Synthetic Data for Learning Motion Representations
summary: Synthetic data offers a compelling path to scalable pretraining when real-world data is scarce, but models pretrained on synthetic data often fail to transfer reliably to deployment settings. We study this problem in full-body human motion, where large-scale data collection is infeasible but essential for wearable-based Human Activity Recognition (HAR), and where synthetic motion can be generated from motion-capture-derived representations. We pretrain motion time-series models using such synthetic data and evaluate their transfer across diverse downstream HAR tasks. Our results show that synthetic pretraining improves generalisation when mixed with real data or scaled sufficiently. We also demonstrate that large-scale motion-capture pretraining yields only marginal gains due to domain mismatch with wearable signals, clarifying key sim-to-real challenges and the limits and opportunities of synthetic motion data for transferable HAR representations.

AI.tldr: This paper explores using synthetic data for scalable pretraining in Human Activity Recognition (HAR) tasks and evaluates its effectiveness across diverse downstream tasks.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the challenge of scarce real-world data for Human Activity Recognition tasks and to evaluate whether synthetic data can reliably improve transfer learning in wearable-based HAR systems.
AI.method: Synthetic motion data generated from motion-capture-derived representations is used to pretrain models. These models' performance is then evaluated on various downstream HAR tasks to assess their generalization capability.
AI.result: Synthetic pretraining improves generalization when combined with real data or scaled sufficiently. However, large-scale motion-capture pretraining shows limited gains due to domain mismatch, highlighting the sim-to-real challenges.
AI.conclusion: Synthetic data holds potential for transferable HAR representations but must be carefully mixed or scaled. The study emphasizes the limitations and opportunities of synthetic motion data in domain transfer scenarios.

title: In-the-Wild Model Organisms: Mitigating Undesirable Emergent Behaviors in Production LLM Post-Training via Data Attribution
summary: We propose activation-based data attribution, a method that traces behavioral changes in post-trained language models to responsible training datapoints. By computing activation-difference vectors for both test prompts and preference pairs and ranking by cosine similarity, we identify datapoints that cause specific behaviors and validate these attributions causally by retraining with modified data. Clustering behavior-datapoint similarity matrices also enables unsupervised discovery of emergent behaviors. Applying this to OLMo 2's production DPO training, we surfaced distractor-triggered compliance: a harmful behavior where the model complies with dangerous requests when benign formatting instructions are appended. Filtering top-ranked datapoints reduces this behavior by 63% while switching their labels achieves 78%. Our method outperforms gradient-based attribution and LLM-judge baselines while being over 10 times cheaper than both. This in-the-wild model organism - emerging from contaminated preference data rather than deliberate injection - provides a realistic benchmark for safety techniques.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a method to attribute specific behaviors in post-trained language models to training datapoints using activation-based analysis, enabling both discovery and mitigation of harmful behaviors.
AI.motivation: The study aims to trace and mitigate harmful or emergent behaviors in large language models, particularly those arising from contaminated training data.
AI.method: The method involves computing activation-difference vectors, ranking datapoints by cosine similarity to pinpoint the sources of behaviors, and validating these attributions through retraining with modified data.
AI.result: Applying the method to a language model's training data significantly reduced harmful behaviors, achieving a reduction of 63% by filtering specific data and 78% by switching their labels.
AI.conclusion: Activation-based data attribution effectively identifies and mitigates harmful behaviors in language models, offering a more efficient approach than existing methods and laying the foundation for improved safety in AI systems.

title: Token-Efficient Change Detection in LLM APIs
summary:
Remote change detection in LLMs is a difficult problem. Existing methods are either too expensive for deployment at scale, or require initial white-box access to model weights or grey-box access to log probabilities. We aim to achieve both low cost and strict black-box operation, observing only output tokens.
  Our approach hinges on specific inputs we call Border Inputs, for which there exists more than one output top token. From a statistical perspective, optimal change detection depends on the model's Jacobian and the Fisher information of the output distribution. Analyzing these quantities in low-temperature regimes shows that border inputs enable powerful change detection tests.
  Building on this insight, we propose the Black-Box Border Input Tracking (B3IT) scheme. Extensive in-vivo and in-vitro experiments show that border inputs are easily found for non-reasoning tested endpoints, and achieve performance on par with the best available grey-box approaches. B3IT reduces costs by $30\times$ compared to existing methods, while operating in a strict black-box setting.

AI.tldr: This paper addresses the challenge of remote change detection in large language models (LLMs) with a novel and cost-effective black-box approach using output tokens.
AI.motivation: Existing methods for change detection in LLMs are either too expensive for large-scale deployment or require access to model internals (weights or log probabilities), which is not always feasible. This research strives to provide an efficient, cost-effective, and purely black-box solution for detecting changes in LLMs.
AI.method: The authors introduce the concept of 'Border Inputs,' which are inputs that provoke ambiguity in model outputs by yielding multiple top tokens. They analyze the mathematical properties (Jacobians and Fisher information) of these inputs in low-temperature settings and propose a novel Black-Box Border Input Tracking (B3IT) scheme as a practical implementation.
AI.result: The proposed B3IT scheme demonstrates strong performance on par with existing grey-box methods for non-reasoning tasks, reducing costs by 30× and requiring only black-box access to output tokens. The experiments validate the effectiveness of border inputs in detecting changes.
AI.conclusion: Border inputs are a key enabler for low-cost remote change detection in LLMs under strict black-box constraints. The B3IT method is shown to be highly effective without relying on internal model access, making it a practical solution for scalable deployment.

title: GRASP: group-Shapley feature selection for patients
summary: Feature selection remains a major challenge in medical prediction, where existing approaches such as LASSO often lack robustness and interpretability. We introduce GRASP, a novel framework that couples Shapley value driven attribution with group $L_{21}$ regularization to extract compact and non-redundant feature sets. GRASP first distills group level importance scores from a pretrained tree model via SHAP, then enforces structured sparsity through group $L_{21}$ regularized logistic regression, yielding stable and interpretable selections. Extensive comparisons with LASSO, SHAP, and deep learning based methods show that GRASP consistently delivers comparable or superior predictive accuracy, while identifying fewer, less redundant, and more stable features.

AI.tldr: GRASP is a new framework combining SHAP and group L21 regularization to improve feature selection in medical prediction.
AI.motivation: Feature selection in medical predictions faces challenges with robustness and interpretability using current methods like LASSO.
AI.method: GRASP integrates SHAP's importance scoring with group L21 regularized logistic regression for compact and stable feature selection.
AI.result: GRASP outperforms LASSO, SHAP, and deep learning-based methods in accuracy and stability, while identifying fewer redundant features.
AI.conclusion: The GRASP framework offers a robust and interpretable solution for medical feature selection, addressing the limitations of existing approaches.

title: General Flexible $f$-divergence for Challenging Offline RL Datasets with Low Stochasticity and Diverse Behavior Policies
comment: Extended version of the full paper with the appendix accepted at AAMAS 2026
summary: Offline RL algorithms aim to improve upon the behavior policy that produces the collected data while constraining the learned policy to be within the support of the dataset. However, practical offline datasets often contain examples with little diversity or limited exploration of the environment, and from multiple behavior policies with diverse expertise levels. Limited exploration can impair the offline RL algorithm's ability to estimate \textit{Q} or \textit{V} values, while constraining towards diverse behavior policies can be overly conservative. Such datasets call for a balance between the RL objective and behavior policy constraints. We first identify the connection between $f$-divergence and optimization constraint on the Bellman residual through a more general Linear Programming form for RL and the convex conjugate. Following this, we introduce the general flexible function formulation for the $f$-divergence to incorporate an adaptive constraint on algorithms' learning objectives based on the offline training dataset. Results from experiments on the MuJoCo, Fetch, and AdroitHand environments show the correctness of the proposed LP form and the potential of the flexible $f$-divergence in improving performance for learning from a challenging dataset when applied to a compatible constrained optimization algorithm.

AI.tldr: This paper addresses challenges in Offline RL and proposes utilizing flexible $f$-divergence constraints for balancing the RL objective and behavior policy constraints, improving performance in environments with limited or diverse datasets.
AI.motivation: Offline RL faces challenges with datasets lacking exploration diversity or containing examples from behavior policies with varied expertise, creating difficulties in estimating values and overly conservative constraints.
AI.method: The authors introduce a flexible $f$-divergence formulation based on convex conjugates and Linear Programming forms for RL to adaptively constrain learning objectives based on dataset characteristics.
AI.result: Experiments on MuJoCo, Fetch, and AdroitHand environments validate the LP formulation and demonstrate improved performance using the proposed method for challenging datasets.
AI.conclusion: The flexible $f$-divergence formulation enhances Offline RL by adaptively balancing constraints and objectives, showing promise for robust learning from diverse and challenging offline datasets.

title: Direct Learning of Calibration-Aware Uncertainty for Neural PDE Surrogates
summary: Neural PDE surrogates are often deployed in data-limited or partially observed regimes where downstream decisions depend on calibrated uncertainty in addition to low prediction error. Existing approaches obtain uncertainty through ensemble replication, fixed stochastic noise such as dropout, or post hoc calibration. Cross-regularized uncertainty learns uncertainty parameters during training using gradients routed through a held-out regularization split. The predictor is optimized on the training split for fit, while low-dimensional uncertainty controls are optimized on the regularization split to reduce train-test mismatch, yielding regime-adaptive uncertainty without per-regime noise tuning. The framework can learn continuous noise levels at the output head, within hidden features, or within operator-specific components such as spectral modes. We instantiate the approach in Fourier Neural Operators and evaluate on APEBench sweeps over observed fraction and training-set size. Across these sweeps, the learned predictive distributions are better calibrated on held-out splits and the resulting uncertainty fields concentrate in high-error regions in one-step spatial diagnostics.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a novel method for uncertainty estimation in neural PDE surrogates by leveraging cross-regularized training to adapt these models for reliable predictions even in data-limited scenarios.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the need for calibrated uncertainty in neural PDE surrogates often deployed in data-limited or partially observed settings.
AI.method: The method introduces cross-regularized uncertainty, which learns uncertainty parameters during training by routing gradients through a held-out regularization split and optimizing predictor fit and uncertainty controls separately.
AI.result: The novel approach demonstrates improved calibrated predictive distributions on held-out splits and localizes uncertainty in high-error regions during evaluations using Fourier Neural Operators on APEBench sweeps.
AI.conclusion: Cross-regularized uncertainty provides regime-adaptive uncertainty without per-regime noise tuning, enhancing reliability in spatial diagnostics and low data scenarios.

title: Statistical Learning Analysis of Physics-Informed Neural Networks
summary: We study the training and performance of physics-informed learning for initial and boundary value problems (IBVP) with physics-informed neural networks (PINNs) from a statistical learning perspective. Specifically, we restrict ourselves to parameterizations with hard initial and boundary condition constraints and reformulate the problem of estimating PINN parameters as a statistical learning problem. From this perspective, the physics penalty on the IBVP residuals can be better understood not as a regularizing term bus as an infinite source of indirect data, and the learning process as fitting the PINN distribution of residuals $p(y \mid x, t, w) q(x, t) $ to the true data-generating distribution $δ(0) q(x, t)$ by minimizing the Kullback-Leibler divergence between the true and PINN distributions. Furthermore, this analysis show that physics-informed learning with PINNs is a singular learning problem, and we employ singular learning theory tools, namely the so-called Local Learning Coefficient (Lau et al., 2025) to analyze the estimates of PINN parameters obtained via stochastic optimization for a heat equation IBVP. Finally, we discuss implications of this analysis on the quantification of predictive uncertainty of PINNs and the extrapolation capacity of PINNs.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) for initial and boundary value problems (IBVP), introducing a statistical learning perspective to understand their training process.
AI.motivation: To better understand and improve the behavior and training of PINNs for solving IBVPs, particularly focusing on their statistical foundation and generalization capabilities.
AI.method: They reformulate the PINN training process as minimizing the Kullback-Leibler divergence between the true IBVP data distribution and the PINN's residual distribution, with analysis using singular learning theory and the Local Learning Coefficient.
AI.result: The study highlights PINN training as a singular learning problem and provides insights into parameter estimation, predictive uncertainty quantification, and extrapolation capabilities for solving a heat equation IBVP.
AI.conclusion: Physics-informed learning for PINNs can be viewed as leveraging indirect data sources rather than regularization, making their statistical learning dynamics and uncertainty quantification critical for broader applications.

title: From Natural Language to Materials Discovery:The Materials Knowledge Navigation Agent
summary: Accelerating the discovery of high-performance materials remains a central challenge across energy, electronics, and aerospace technologies, where traditional workflows depend heavily on expert intuition and computationally expensive simulations. Here we introduce the Materials Knowledge Navigation Agent (MKNA), a language-driven system that translates natural-language scientific intent into executable actions for database retrieval, property prediction, structure generation, and stability evaluation. Beyond automating tool invocation, MKNA autonomously extracts quantitative thresholds and chemically meaningful design motifs from literature and database evidence, enabling data-grounded hypothesis formation. Applied to the search for high-Debye-temperature ceramics, the agent identifies a literature-supported screening criterion (Theta_D > 800 K), rediscovers canonical ultra-stiff materials such as diamond, SiC, SiN, and BeO, and proposes thermodynamically stable, previously unreported Be-C-rich compounds that populate the sparsely explored 1500-1700 K regime. These results demonstrate that MKNA not only finds stable candidates but also reconstructs interpretable design heuristics, establishing a generalizable platform for autonomous, language-guided materials exploration.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces MKNA, a system that uses natural language to execute material discovery tasks, predict materials properties, and generate hypotheses, significantly speeding up materials research.
AI.motivation: To tackle the challenge of discovering high-performance materials across various industries by reducing reliance on intuition and expensive computational methods.
AI.method: Developed MKNA, a language-based system that automates tasks like database retrieval, property prediction, and stability analysis while independently interpreting literature and identifying design principles.
AI.result: The system identified high-Debye-temperature ceramics, rediscovered known materials, and suggested novel stable compounds in an unexplored temperature range.
AI.conclusion: MKNA is a generalizable and autonomous framework for material discovery, capable of hypothesis formation and advancing understanding in materials science research.

title: The Offline-Frontier Shift: Diagnosing Distributional Limits in Generative Multi-Objective Optimization
summary: Offline multi-objective optimization (MOO) aims to recover Pareto-optimal designs given a finite, static dataset. Recent generative approaches, including diffusion models, show strong performance under hypervolume, yet their behavior under other established MOO metrics is less understood. We show that generative methods systematically underperform evolutionary alternatives with respect to other metrics, such as generational distance. We relate this failure mode to the offline-frontier shift, i.e., the displacement of the offline dataset from the Pareto front, which acts as a fundamental limitation in offline MOO. We argue that overcoming this limitation requires out-of-distribution sampling in objective space (via an integral probability metric) and empirically observe that generative methods remain conservatively close to the offline objective distribution. Our results position offline MOO as a distribution-shift--limited problem and provide a diagnostic lens for understanding when and why generative optimization methods fail.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates why generative methods underperform in offline multi-objective optimization (MOO), highlighting their shortcomings in specific metrics due to the offline-frontier shift.
AI.motivation: To address gaps in understanding the performance of generative methods in offline multi-objective optimization with metrics beyond hypervolume, and to identify reasons behind their limitations.
AI.method: The study evaluates generative methods in MOO, examines their systematic underperformance relative to evolutionary approaches, and links this to the offline-frontier shift. It introduces the need for out-of-distribution sampling in the objective space.
AI.result: Generative methods underperform with respect to metrics like generational distance due to an offline-frontier shift, with observed conservative behavior in objective distributions.
AI.conclusion: The study frames offline MOO as a distribution-shift-limited problem, offering insights into the conditions where generative methods fail and emphasizing the importance of understanding these shifts.

title: Asymmetric Prompt Weighting for Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards
summary: Reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards has driven recent advances in LLM post-training, in particular for reasoning. Policy optimization algorithms generate a number of responses for a given prompt and then effectively weight the corresponding gradients depending on the rewards. The most popular algorithms including GRPO, DAPO, and RLOO focus on ambiguous prompts, i.e., prompts with intermediate success probability, while downgrading gradients with very easy and very hard prompts. In this paper, we consider asymmetric prompt weightings that assign higher weights to prompts with low, or even zero, empirical success probability. We find that asymmetric weighting particularly benefits from-scratch RL (as in R1-Zero), where training traverses a wide accuracy range, and less so in post-SFT RL where the model already starts at high accuracy. We also provide theory that characterizes prompt weights which minimize the time needed to raise success probability from an initial level to a target accuracy under a fixed update budget. In low-success regimes, where informative responses are rare and response cost dominates, these optimal weights become asymmetric, upweighting low success probabilities and thereby accelerating effective-time convergence.

AI.tldr: This paper explores asymmetric prompt weightings in reinforcement learning to enhance low success probability scenarios, demonstrating benefits for from-scratch RL and providing theoretical insights.
AI.motivation: Current RL algorithms in LLM post-training unevenly handle prompts based on success difficulty, limiting gains in scenarios with very low success probabilities.
AI.method: The authors propose asymmetric prompt weightings that assign higher weights to prompts with low or zero success probabilities, particularly for low-success situations in from-scratch RL (R1-Zero).
AI.result: Asymmetric weighting accelerates convergence by effectively emphasizing low-success prompts. The paper also develops a theoretical framework for optimal prompt weight minimization strategies.
AI.conclusion: Asymmetric weightings improve reinforcement learning efficiency and guide training strategies, particularly in challenging low-success contexts for language models.

title: Blind Gods and Broken Screens: Architecting a Secure, Intent-Centric Mobile Agent Operating System
summary:
The evolution of Large Language Models (LLMs) has shifted mobile computing from App-centric interactions to system-level autonomous agents. Current implementations predominantly rely on a "Screen-as-Interface" paradigm, which inherits structural vulnerabilities and conflicts with the mobile ecosystem's economic foundations. In this paper, we conduct a systematic security analysis of state-of-the-art mobile agents using Doubao Mobile Assistant as a representative case. We decompose the threat landscape into four dimensions - Agent Identity, External Interface, Internal Reasoning, and Action Execution - revealing critical flaws such as fake App identity, visual spoofing, indirect prompt injection, and unauthorized privilege escalation stemming from a reliance on unstructured visual data.
  To address these challenges, we propose Aura, an Agent Universal Runtime Architecture for a clean-slate secure agent OS. Aura replaces brittle GUI scraping with a structured, agent-native interaction model. It adopts a Hub-and-Spoke topology where a privileged System Agent orchestrates intent, sandboxed App Agents execute domain-specific tasks, and the Agent Kernel mediates all communication. The Agent Kernel enforces four defense pillars: (i) cryptographic identity binding via a Global Agent Registry; (ii) semantic input sanitization through a multilayer Semantic Firewall; (iii) cognitive integrity via taint-aware memory and plan-trajectory alignment; and (iv) granular access control with non-deniable auditing. Evaluation on MobileSafetyBench shows that, compared to Doubao, Aura improves low-risk Task Success Rate from roughly 75% to 94.3%, reduces high-risk Attack Success Rate from roughly 40% to 4.4%, and achieves near-order-of-magnitude latency gains. These results demonstrate Aura as a viable, secure alternative to the "Screen-as-Interface" paradigm.

AI.tldr: The paper identifies security vulnerabilities in current mobile agents using Doubao as a case study, proposing a secure alternative architecture called Aura for safer and more efficient interactions.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address the security flaws and inefficiencies in the "Screen-as-Interface" paradigm used by current mobile agents, which are becoming a critical component of mobile ecosystems.
AI.method: The authors conduct a systematic security analysis of state-of-the-art mobile agents and propose Aura, a secure runtime architecture with multiple defense mechanisms.
AI.result: Aura outperforms Doubao significantly by increasing low-risk Task Success Rate (75% to 94.3%), reducing high-risk Attack Success Rate (40% to 4.4%), and achieving latency improvements.
AI.conclusion: Aura proves to be a secure and efficient alternative to the "Screen-as-Interface" paradigm, mitigating critical vulnerabilities and improving operational metrics.

title: Traceable, Enforceable, and Compensable Participation: A Participation Ledger for People-Centered AI Governance
comment: Presented at PAIRS: Participatory AI Research & Practice Symposium
summary: Participatory approaches are widely invoked in AI governance, yet participation rarely translates into durable influence. In public sector and civic AI systems, community contributions such as deliberations, annotations, prompts, and incident reports are often recorded informally, weakly linked to system updates, and disconnected from enforceable rights or sustained compensation. As a result, participation is frequently symbolic rather than accountable. We introduce the Participation Ledger, a machine readable and auditable framework that operationalizes participation as traceable influence, enforceable authority, and compensable labor. The ledger represents participation as an influence graph that links contributed artifacts to verified changes in AI systems, including datasets, prompts, adapters, policies, guardrails, and evaluation suites. It integrates three elements: a Participation Evidence Standard documenting consent, privacy, compensation, and reuse terms; an influence tracing mechanism that connects system updates to replayable before and after tests, enabling longitudinal monitoring of commitments; and encoded rights and incentives. Capability Vouchers allow authorized community stewards to request or constrain specific system capabilities within defined boundaries, while Participation Credits support ongoing recognition and compensation when contributed tests continue to provide value. We ground the framework in four urban AI and public space governance deployments and provide a machine readable schema, templates, and an evaluation plan for assessing traceability, enforceability, and compensation in practice.

AI.tldr: AI governance often involves participatory approaches, but these contributions lack durable influence. The Participation Ledger aims to make such contributions traceable, enforceable, and properly compensated.
AI.motivation: The paper seeks to address the issue of symbolic participation in AI systems, ensuring that contributions from communities have tangible outcomes and are linked to enforceable influence, rights, and compensation.
AI.method: The Participation Ledger framework uses a traceable influence graph to connect contributions with system updates. It incorporates documented consent and reuse terms, an influence tracing mechanism, and encoded rights and incentives.
AI.result: The framework has been applied in four urban AI deployments. It includes schemas, templates, and evaluation plans to assess its effectiveness in ensuring accountability and compensation.
AI.conclusion: This approach enhances the impact and accountability of participatory contributions in AI governance, focusing on compensable labor and enforceable changes in AI systems.

title: What do people want to fact-check?
summary: Research on misinformation has focused almost exclusively on supply, asking what falsehoods circulate, who produces them, and whether corrections work. A basic demand-side question remains unanswered. When ordinary people can fact-check anything they want, what do they actually ask about? We provide the first large-scale evidence on this question by analyzing close to 2{,}500 statements submitted by 457 participants to an open-ended AI fact-checking system. Each claim is classified along five semantic dimensions (domain, epistemic form, verifiability, target entity, and temporal reference), producing a behavioral map of public verification demand. Three findings stand out. First, users range widely across topics but default to a narrow epistemic repertoire, overwhelmingly submitting simple descriptive claims about present-day observables. Second, roughly one in four requests concerns statements that cannot be empirically resolved, including moral judgments, speculative predictions, and subjective evaluations, revealing a systematic mismatch between what users seek from fact-checking tools and what such tools can deliver. Third, comparison with the FEVER benchmark dataset exposes sharp structural divergences across all five dimensions, indicating that standard evaluation corpora encode a synthetic claim environment that does not resemble real-world verification needs. These results reframe fact-checking as a demand-driven problem and identify where current AI systems and benchmarks are misaligned with the uncertainty people actually experience.

AI.tldr: This paper examines the types of claims public users submit to an AI fact-checking system and identifies key mismatches between public needs and current fact-checking tools.
AI.motivation: To understand what claims people actually fact-check and assess the alignment between real-world verification demands and existing AI fact-checking tools.
AI.method: Analyzed 2,500 claims submitted by 457 users to an AI fact-checking system, categorizing them along five semantic dimensions: domain, epistemic form, verifiability, target entity, and temporal reference.
AI.result: Findings include: users often ask about narrow, descriptive claims; many queries are unverifiable (e.g., moral, speculative, or subjective); existing benchmarks like FEVER poorly represent real-world fact-checking needs.
AI.conclusion: Fact-checking should shift towards addressing demand-driven public verification needs, with tools and benchmarks better tailored to the types of claims people actually submit.

title: TabICLv2: A better, faster, scalable, and open tabular foundation model
summary: Tabular foundation models, such as TabPFNv2 and TabICL, have recently dethroned gradient-boosted trees at the top of predictive benchmarks, demonstrating the value of in-context learning for tabular data. We introduce TabICLv2, a new state-of-the-art foundation model for regression and classification built on three pillars: (1) a novel synthetic data generation engine designed for high pretraining diversity; (2) various architectural innovations, including a new scalable softmax in attention improving generalization to larger datasets without prohibitive long-sequence pretraining; and (3) optimized pretraining protocols, notably replacing AdamW with the Muon optimizer. On the TabArena and TALENT benchmarks, TabICLv2 without any tuning surpasses the performance of the current state of the art, RealTabPFN-2.5 (hyperparameter-tuned, ensembled, and fine-tuned on real data). With only moderate pretraining compute, TabICLv2 generalizes effectively to million-scale datasets under 50GB GPU memory while being markedly faster than RealTabPFN-2.5. We provide extensive ablation studies to quantify these contributions and commit to open research by first releasing inference code and model weights at https://github.com/soda-inria/tabicl, with synthetic data engine and pretraining code to follow.

AI.tldr: TabICLv2 sets a new benchmark in predictive performance for regression and classification on tabular data, surpassing previous state-of-the-art models through innovative methods in pretraining diversity, attention mechanisms, and optimization.
AI.motivation: To further improve predictive performance on tabular data using foundation models and establish new benchmarks while addressing limitations in current state-of-the-art models.
AI.method: Developed TabICLv2 using a synthetic data generation engine, scalable softmax for attention, and an optimized pretraining protocol with the Muon optimizer. Conducted extensive comparisons and ablation studies.
AI.result: TabICLv2 outperforms RealTabPFN-2.5 on TabArena and TALENT benchmarks without tuning, scales effectively to large datasets under resource constraints, and demonstrates faster inference.
AI.conclusion: TabICLv2 pushes the boundaries of performance for tabular predictive models, combining innovations for adaptability, efficiency, and open research access to accelerate advancements in the field.

title: Enhancing IMU-Based Online Handwriting Recognition via Contrastive Learning with Zero Inference Overhead
summary: Online handwriting recognition using inertial measurement units opens up handwriting on paper as input for digital devices. Doing it on edge hardware improves privacy and lowers latency, but entails memory constraints. To address this, we propose Error-enhanced Contrastive Handwriting Recognition (ECHWR), a training framework designed to improve feature representation and recognition accuracy without increasing inference costs. ECHWR utilizes a temporary auxiliary branch that aligns sensor signals with semantic text embeddings during the training phase. This alignment is maintained through a dual contrastive objective: an in-batch contrastive loss for general modality alignment and a novel error-based contrastive loss that distinguishes between correct signals and synthetic hard negatives. The auxiliary branch is discarded after training, which allows the deployed model to keep its original, efficient architecture. Evaluations on the OnHW-Words500 dataset show that ECHWR significantly outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, reducing character error rates by up to 7.4% on the writer-independent split and 10.4% on the writer-dependent split. Finally, although our ablation studies indicate that solving specific challenges require specific architectural and objective configurations, error-based contrastive loss shows its effectiveness for handling unseen writing styles.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes ECHWR, a training framework for online handwriting recognition using inertial measurement units, which improves accuracy and efficiency without increasing inference costs.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to enhance online handwriting recognition using edge hardware, which ensures better privacy and reduced latency but faces memory constraints.
AI.method: ECHWR introduces a temporary auxiliary branch for training, aligning sensor signals with semantic text embeddings using a dual contrastive loss: in-batch contrastive loss for modality alignment and error-based contrastive loss to handle hard negatives. The auxiliary branch is removed after training.
AI.result: ECHWR achieves state-of-the-art performance on the OnHW-Words500 dataset, reducing character error rates by 7.4% in writer-independent and 10.4% in writer-dependent splits.
AI.conclusion: The proposed error-based contrastive loss is effective in tackling unseen writing styles, and the framework improves recognition accuracy while maintaining efficient architecture.

title: Validating Interpretability in siRNA Efficacy Prediction: A Perturbation-Based, Dataset-Aware Protocol
summary: Saliency maps are increasingly used as \emph{design guidance} in siRNA efficacy prediction, yet attribution methods are rarely validated before motivating sequence edits. We introduce a \textbf{pre-synthesis gate}: a protocol for \emph{counterfactual sensitivity faithfulness} that tests whether mutating high-saliency positions changes model output more than composition-matched controls. Cross-dataset transfer reveals two failure modes that would otherwise go undetected: \emph{faithful-but-wrong} (saliency valid, predictions fail) and \emph{inverted saliency} (top-saliency edits less impactful than random). Strikingly, models trained on mRNA-level assays collapse on a luciferase reporter dataset, demonstrating that protocol shifts can silently invalidate deployment. Across four benchmarks, 19/20 fold instances pass; the single failure shows inverted saliency. A biology-informed regularizer (BioPrior) strengthens saliency faithfulness with modest, dataset-dependent predictive trade-offs. Our results establish saliency validation as essential pre-deployment practice for explanation-guided therapeutic design. Code is available at https://github.com/shadi97kh/BioPrior.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a protocol to validate saliency maps' efficacy in siRNA prediction and reveals two significant failure modes, emphasizing the critical role of saliency validation pre-deployment.
AI.motivation: To address the lack of validation for saliency maps before they are used to motivate sequence edits in siRNA efficacy prediction.
